Module module2023s1.assignment2
Package lms.grid

Class Coordinate

Object
Coordinate
public class Coordinate extends Object
This is the Coordinate class, which is used to represent coordinates on a hexagonal grid. (If you have read the GameLoader class, this is not the same as the positional id which is generated when parsing nodes.) This class represents a hexagon in "point-top orientation": 

 Top Left      / \  Right Top
 Left          | |  Right
 Bottom Left   \ /  Bottom Right

There are multiple ways to mathematically represent a hexagonal grid. Because programming with classes allows you to hide abstractions from other classes using private methods and variables, the implementation approach "doesn't matter".

When loading a grid, you will elect a point as the origin, and then use the methods provided to navigate around and generate new Coordinates.

This code is provided to assist you in assignment 2

  • Constructor Details

    • Coordinate

      public Coordinate()
      This should be the origin Coordinate, A special coordinate that must exist in every game map. Only Coordinates that have a direct connection (that is, not isolated) will be drawn onto the game map.

    • Coordinate

      public Coordinate(int x, int y, int z)
      Creates a Coordinate with three components.
      Parameters:
      x - first arg
      y - second arg
      z - third arg

    • Coordinate

      public Coordinate(int x, int y)
      Creates a Coordinate with two components, calcuating the third coordinate.
      Parameters:
      x - first arg
      y - second arg, z is defined as -x - y

    • getDirection

      public Orientation getDirection(Coordinate coordinate)
      Gets the direction required to travel to get from this coordinate to the reference coordinate
      Parameters:
      coordinate - reference to be examined
      Returns:
      Orientation direction of travel
      Requires:
      isNeighbour(coordinate) == true || you can travel from this coordinate to the other in a straight line
      Ensures:
      Orientation returns is correct as a direct relation
